descript.abstract: This data layer contains elementary school boundaries. The elementary school areas are, in turn, aggregated to create middle or high school boundaries. Some areas of the city have options for school attendance at the elementary or middle school level. This data layer includes areas showing the limits of those boundaries.
descript.purpose: This layer is intended for researchers, students, and policy makers for reference and mapping purposes, and may be used for basic applications such as viewing, querying, and map output production, or to provide a basemap to support graphical overlays and analysis with other spatial data.This layer will provide a basemap for layers related to socio-economic and education planning and policy-making purposes. More advanced user applications may focus on urban planning, public works, or utilities purposes (including defining boundaries, managing assets and facilities, integrating attribute databases with geographic features, spatial analysis, and presentation output.)
descript.supplinf: This data layer is edited as-needed by the GIS Administrator. While redistricting will begin in 2003 the elementary school boundaries will not change - only the feeder patterns will. There is an updated file to reflect these changes. This will replace the current file when the changes take effect.

idinfo.accconst: Access is granted to licensee (Harvard University) only. Available only to Harvard University affiliates.
idinfo.datacred: GIS data supplied by City of Newton GIS.
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows NT Version 4.0 (Build 1381) Service Pack 6; ESRI ArcCatalog 8.2.0.700

dataqual.logic: For layers containing line or polygon features, Newton's data layers are "topologically clean". This was verified with Arc/Info software version 7.x in 1998 and is an ongoing part of data maintenance for the relevant data layers.

horizpa.horizpar: No systematic and quantitative review of property boundary accuracy has ever been conducted. However, several qualitative observations based on experience using the data are possible. The street right-of-way lines overlay the orthophoto base map very well, falling on or close to the apparent back-of-sidewalk visible on the photos.The edge-of-pavement data layer was compiled from aerial photography for Boston Edison to an absolute accuracy specification of +/- 2.5 feet. Again, the right-of-way lines match up well in this comparison. Less is known about the accuracy of the internal property boundaries. Casual observations suggest they are sometimes as accurate as the right-of-way lines and sometimes much less. Some observations of boundary line discrepancies relative to property boundary lines such as fences and hedges visible on the orthophotos indicate that internal property boundaries may be off by at least +/- 5 feet.From Street Centerlines Datalayer:The objective in creating this data layer was simply to have a line representing each street block fall in the street right-of-way. Streets represented include both public and private and built and un-built ("paper") streets.

srcinfo.srccontr: Some Attribute information for this layer were derived from the PARCELS datalayer.

procstep.procdesc: These boundaries are defined by streets and property boundaries. Street center lines and property boundary lines were copied into a separate file. Additional lines were added as needed to close the areas. Then polygon topology was created.
The original shape file was imported to an ArcSDE Layer.

altsys.altenc: Explicit elevation coordinate included with horizontal coordinates
